Items.problem: Camera.main property uses FindGameObjectsWithTag() internally and doesn't cache the result.
Items.solution: It is advised to cache and use the camera component obtained from Game object instead.

Items.problem: WebCamTexture.GetPixels() allocates managed memory.
Items.solution: Use WebCamTexture.GetPixels32() instead.

Items.problem: WebCamTexture.GetPixels32() allocates managed memory if a suitable array is not provided as a parameter.
Items.solution: Ensure that you pass an array of Color32[] to this API method for it to fill out, to avoid creating a new array every time the method is called.

Items.problem: Some versions of GeometryUtility.CalculateFrustumPlanes() allocate managed memory.
Items.solution: Ensure that you use the CalculateFrustumPlanes(Matrix4x4 worldToProjectionMatrix, Plane[] planes) version of this API method, in order to be able to pass a pre-allocated Array of Planes.

Items.problem: Resources.FindObjectsOfTypeAll() allocates managed memory.
Items.solution: Use Resources.FindObjectsOfTypeNonAlloc() instead.

Items.problem: Texture2D.GetPixels() allocates managed memory.
Items.solution: Use Texture2D.GetRawTextureData() instead. This method returns a NativeArray of pixel data, and so does not allocate managed memory.

Items.problem: Texture2D.GetPixels32() allocates managed memory.
Items.solution: Use Texture2D.GetRawTextureData() instead. This method returns a NativeArray of pixel data, and so does not allocate managed memory.

Items.problem: Rigidbody.SweepTestAll() allocates managed memory.
Items.solution: Use Rigidbody.SweepTestNonAlloc() instead.

Items.problem: Component.GetComponentsInChildren() allocates managed memory.
Items.solution: Ensure you are using one of the versions of GameObject.GetComponentsInChildren() which accepts a List<T> as a parameter and populates it with the components it finds.

Items.problem: Component.GetComponentsInParent() allocates managed memory.
Items.solution: Ensure you are using one of the versions of GameObject.GetComponentsInParent() which accepts a List<T> as a parameter and populates it with the components it finds.

Items.problem: Some versions of GameObject.GetComponentsInChildren() allocate managed memory.
Items.solution: Ensure you are using one of the versions of GameObject.GetComponentsInChildren() which accepts a List<T> as a parameter and populates it with the components it finds.

Items.problem: Some versions of GameObject.GetComponentsInParent() allocate managed memory.
Items.solution: Ensure you are using one of the versions of GameObject.GetComponentsInParent() which accepts a List<T> as a parameter and populates it with the components it finds.

Items.problem: OnTriggerStay() methods can detrimentally affect performance if they perform a lot of processing or if there are many Colliders which implement this method.
Items.solution: Profile CPU performance to look for bottlenecks, examine the contents of all OnTriggerStay() methods, and consider refactoring code to not use them.

Items.problem: OnTriggerStay() methods can detrimentally affect performance if they perform a lot of processing or if there are many MonoBehaviours which implement this method.
Items.solution: Profile CPU performance to look for bottlenecks, examine the contents of all OnTriggerStay() methods, and consider refactoring code to not use them.

Items.problem: OnTriggerStay2D() methods can detrimentally affect performance if they perform a lot of processing or if there are many Collider2Ds which implement this method.
Items.solution: Profile CPU performance to look for bottlenecks, examine the contents of all OnTriggerStay2D() methods, and consider refactoring code to not use them.

Items.problem: OnTriggerStay2D() methods can detrimentally affect performance if they perform a lot of processing or if there are many MonoBehaviours which implement this method.
Items.solution: Profile CPU performance to look for bottlenecks, examine the contents of all OnTriggerStay2D() methods, and consider refactoring code to not use them.

Items.problem: OnCollisionStay() methods can detrimentally affect performance if they perform a lot of processing or if there are many Colliders which implement this method.
Items.solution: Profile CPU performance to look for bottlenecks, examine the contents of all OnCollisionStay() methods, and consider refactoring code to not use them.

Items.problem: OnCollisionStay() methods can detrimentally affect performance if they perform a lot of processing or if there are many MonoBehaviours which implement this method.
Items.solution: Profile CPU performance to look for bottlenecks, examine the contents of all OnCollisionStay() methods, and consider refactoring code to not use them.

Items.problem: OnCollisionStay() methods can detrimentally affect performance if they perform a lot of processing or if there are many RigidBodies which implement this method.
Items.solution: Profile CPU performance to look for bottlenecks, examine the contents of all OnCollisionStay() methods, and consider refactoring code to not use them.

Items.problem: ImageConversion.LoadImage() defaults to maintaining a CPU-accessible copy of the image. This is a waste of memory if not needed.
Items.solution: If a CPU-accessible copy of the texture is not required, ensure that the markNonReadable flag passed into the method is set to true.

Items.problem: BillboardRenderer.material: this property creates a unique copy of the Renderer's material. This breaks draw call batching and results in a higher number of draw calls, impacting rendering performance.
Items.solution: If possible, use BillboardRenderer.sharedMaterial instead.

Items.problem: Renderer.material: this property creates a unique copy of the Renderer's material. This breaks draw call batching and results in a higher number of draw calls, impacting rendering performance.
Items.solution: If possible, use Renderer.sharedMaterial instead.

Items.problem: TrailRenderer.material: this property creates a unique copy of the Renderer's material. This breaks draw call batching and results in a higher number of draw calls, impacting rendering performance.
Items.solution: If possible, use TrailRenderer.sharedMaterial instead.

Items.problem: LineRenderer.material: this property creates a unique copy of the Renderer's material. This breaks draw call batching and results in a higher number of draw calls, impacting rendering performance.
Items.solution: If possible, use LineRenderer.sharedMaterial instead.

Items.problem: SkinnedMeshRenderer.material: this property creates a unique copy of the Renderer's material. This breaks draw call batching and results in a higher number of draw calls, impacting rendering performance.
Items.solution: If possible, use SkinnedMeshRenderer.sharedMaterial instead.

Items.problem: MeshRenderer.material: this property creates a unique copy of the Renderer's material. This breaks draw call batching and results in a higher number of draw calls, impacting rendering performance.
Items.solution: If possible, use MeshRenderer.sharedMaterial instead.

Items.problem: SpriteRenderer.material: this property creates a unique copy of the Renderer's material. This breaks draw call batching and results in a higher number of draw calls, impacting rendering performance.
Items.solution: If possible, use SpriteRenderer.sharedMaterial instead.

Items.problem: ParticleSystemRenderer.material: this property creates a unique copy of the Renderer's material. This breaks draw call batching and results in a higher number of draw calls, impacting rendering performance.
Items.solution: If possible, use ParticleSystemRenderer.sharedMaterial instead.

Items.problem: SpriteMask.material: this property creates a unique copy of the Renderer's material. This breaks draw call batching and results in a higher number of draw calls, impacting rendering performance.
Items.solution: If possible, use SpriteMask.sharedMaterial instead.

Items.problem: Experimental.U2D.SpriteShapeRenderer.material: this property creates a unique copy of the Renderer's material. This breaks draw call batching and results in a higher number of draw calls, impacting rendering performance.
Items.solution: If possible, use Experimental.U2D.SpriteShapeRenderer.sharedMaterial instead.

Items.problem: Tilemaps.TilemapRenderer.material: this property creates a unique copy of the Renderer's material. This breaks draw call batching and results in a higher number of draw calls, impacting rendering performance.
Items.solution: If possible, use Tilemaps.TilemapRenderer.sharedMaterial instead.

Items.problem: Linq allocates large amounts of managed memory.
Items.solution: We strongly advise against using Linq in any frequently-updated code. Ban its usage from the project entirely, or confine it to initialization code and use it sparingly.

Items.problem: Reflection is slow, and not generally considered performant enough for runtime code.
Items.solution: Remove code which relies on reflection, or minimise its usage, particularly outside of initialization.

Items.problem: ComputeBuffer.GetData() stalls the CPU until the GPU has finished accessing the buffer. This can lead to significant CPU performance problems
Items.solution: Avoid reading back from ComputeBuffers if it is at all possible. If it's unavoidable, profile your project carefully and regularly to monitor the performance impact.

Items.problem: Texture2D.SetPixels() is slower than SetPixels32().
Items.solution: Use Texture2D.SetPixels32() or GetRawTextureData()/Apply() instead.

Items.problem: Texture3D.SetPixels() is slower than SetPixels32().
Items.solution: Use Texture3D.SetPixels32() instead.

Items.problem: Texture2DArray.SetPixels() is slower than SetPixels32().
Items.solution: Use Texture2DArray.SetPixels32() instead.

Items.problem: CubemapArray.SetPixels() is slower than SetPixels32().
Items.solution: Use CubemapArray.SetPixels32() instead.

Items.problem: GameObject.SendMessage() is a very slow and CPU-intensive method.
Items.solution: Implement a custom system to replace SendMessage - get the components you want to send messages and call methods directly on them.

Items.problem: Component.SendMessage() is a very slow and CPU-intensive method.
Items.solution: Implement a custom system to replace SendMessage - get the components you want to send messages and call methods directly on them.

Items.problem: OnGUI() is used by the legacy Immediate Mode GUI (IMGUI), which is extremely CPU-intensive. If a single OnGUI() method is present in a project's code, IMGUI will initialize and consume CPU time.
Items.solution: Remove all OnGUI() methods from the project code.

Items.problem: The property AI.NavMeshPath.corners allocates managed memory.
Items.solution: Use AI.NavMeshPath.GetCornersNonAlloc() instead

Items.problem: The property Animator.parameters allocates managed memory.
Items.solution: Use Animator.GetParameter() instead.
